docs.lead_paragraph: TERRELL WARD BYNUM is a professor of philosophy and director of the Research Center on Computing and Society at Southern Connecticut State University in New Haven. Since 1978, Dr. Bynum, has been conducting research in computer ethics. He was a chairman of Ethicomp 95, an international symposium at De Montford University in Leicester, England, and is one of the organizers of a new computer ethics consortium that has brought together scientists from all over the world.

headline.main: Connecticut Q&A: Dr. Terrell Ward Bynum;The Internet: In Need of a Value System

docs.snippet: TERRELL WARD BYNUM is a professor of philosophy and director of the Research  Center on Computing and Society at Southern Connecticut State University in New  Haven. Since 1978, Dr. Bynum, has been conducting research in computer ethics. He was a...

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR all the much-discussed emphasis on the need to cut costs, the health care system still is rich enough to excite deal makers. Witness the $8.9 billion agreement last week for the purchase of U.S. Healthcare Inc., one of the country's biggest health maintenance organizations. The would-be buyer, the Aetna Life & Casualty Company, is an even bigger health insurance company. Aetna's plans were announced only a few days after a big for-profit hospital chain, the Columbia-HCA Health Corporation, announced an important agreement to buy most of the business of Ohio Blue Cross and Blue Shield, a policyholder-owned insurance company.

headline.main: Health Care In the Era of Capitalism

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re "Queens Old-Timers Uneasy as Asian Influence Grows" (March 31): I don't understand why Councilwoman Julia Harrison finds the growing Asian population in Flushing, Queens, so "discombobulating, very upsetting." Her beliefs that the many Asians coming to the United States have entered illegally and are ungrateful, affluent profiteers looking to exploit this country are unfounded.

headline.main: Asian Immigrants Help New York Thrive

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re your April 1 news article on delays in our claim payments: In 1995, when H.I.P. set out to re-engineer its claims processing system, we had to slow the processing while 500,000 handwritten claims were scanned and transferred to a data base.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re "Court Overturns Ban in New York on Aided Suicides" (front page, April 3): Hospice professionals have identified a new condition afflicting the terminally ill. They call it "failure to die." Its prevalence undercuts the logic of the Federal appeals court ruling authorizing doctors to provide terminally ill patients with lethal drugs.

headline.main: Assisted Suicide Poses Threat to Society

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly 30 years later, the young assistant professor still sticks in the minds of colleagues who heard him at a mathematics seminar in Berkeley -- not for what he said, but for how he behaved. Theodore J. Kaczynski, spoke and then slipped out, skipping the traditional beer party that followed such seminars, an unusual omission for the star of the show. For some of his contemporaries at the University of California at Berkeley, the only memory of Mr. Kaczynski that remains is his shunning that party.

headline.main: Memories of His Brilliance, And Shyness, but Little Else
headline.kicker: ON THE SUSPECT'S TRAIL: THE SUSPECT

docs.lead_paragraph: Faced with a renewed emphasis by Detroit's Big Three auto makers on paring costs, leaders of the United Automobile Workers union made clear at a three-day convention ended here today that they were in no mood for concessions. With the U.A.W.'s triennial round of bargaining approaching this summer with the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation union leaders and auto executives are preparing for labor negotiations aimed at a national agreement that are likely to be the most contentious in many years.

headline.main: U.A.W. Sets Hard Stance In Bargaining

docs.lead_paragraph: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about mergers in the health care industry misstated terms of two recent acquisitions. Wellpoint Health Networks Inc. bought the group life and health division of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, while Healthsource Inc. bought the medical services business of the Provident Life and Accident Insurance Company. Neither buyer acquired an entire company.
